description: From Middle English whale, from Old English hw√¶l (‚Äúwhale‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *hwal, from Proto-Germanic *hwalaz (‚Äúwhale‚Äù) (compare German Wal, Swedish val, Danish and Norwegian Bokm√•l hval, Norwegian Nynorsk kval; compare also Dutch walvis, West Frisian walfisk, from Proto-Indo-European *(s)k ∑√°los (‚Äúsheatfish‚Äù) (compare German Wels, Latin squalus (‚Äúbig sea fish‚Äù), Old Prussian kalis, Ancient Greek ·ºÑœÉœÄŒ±ŒªŒøœÇ (√°spalos), Avestan ê¨êê¨Äê¨≠ê¨Ä‚Äé (kara, ‚Äúkind of fish‚Äù)).

entries.meaning: Any one of numerous large marine mammals comprising an informal group within infraorder Cetacea that usually excludes dolphins and porpoises.
(figuratively) Something, or someone, that is very large.
examples: It was a whale of a job.  [‚Ä¶]  It took two months, and the fair blush of youth off my cheeks.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, as "whale of a ___") Something, or someone, that is excellent.
examples: My own father only wrote one poem in his life as far as I know, but it was a whale of a lyric, the kind you would give your whole life to write, which he did, but that is another story.

entries.meaning: (gambling) In a casino, a person who routinely bets at the maximum limit allowable.
(finance, informal) An investor who deals with very large amounts of money.
(marketing, by extension) A person who spends large amounts of money on things that are marketed to them.

verbs.description: whale (third-person singular simple present whales, present participle whaling, simple past and past participle whaled)

description: Uncertain. Perhaps a variant of wale influenced by whack, whap, etc.

verbs.description: whale (third-person singular simple present whales, present participle whaling, simple past and past participle whaled)

entries.meaning: (slang, transitive) To thrash, to flog, to beat vigorously or soundly.
examples: Brought him back, put him in the stall‚Äîlow stable‚Äîgot out of his reach, and then begun to whale him. Then he kicked up agin;  [‚Ä¶]
